summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Health Services Clinical Encounter form documenting an injury assessment for inmate Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019, after he was found in his cell with a rope around his neck. The document records his medical evaluation, his statement that he did not know how the injury occurred, and notes he was placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who was found in his cell with a rope around his neck and is being assessed for injuries. He is the subject of the medical encounter.

persons.name: MLP
persons.context: The Mid-Level Practitioner (MLP) who conducted the clinical encounter, documented the inmate's injuries, vital signs, and assessment, and placed Epstein on suicide watch.

persons.name: Operational Lt.
persons.context: The operational lieutenant who requested the injury report for inmate Epstein.

connections.description: MLP conducted the medical assessment and evaluation of Epstein's injuries.
The operational lieutenant requested the injury report for Epstein after he was found in his cell.

events.title: Epstein Found with Rope in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit 205-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor, leading to an injury assessment and placement on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical Evaluation and Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein received a medical evaluation for neck injuries described as a circular line of erythema. He was placed on suicide watch and scheduled for follow-up with psychology services.

locations: Special Housing Unit 205-Cell 124 (at NYM - Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York)
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit 205-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor.

Epstein told the medical provider (MLP) he did not know how the injury occurred, stating 'I do not know. Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting.' He could not explain the marks on his neck and did not want to discuss the events leading to them.

The medical assessment noted a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of his neck, approximately 2 inches wide, covering about two-thirds of the neck circumference, with signs of friction in the front.
Epstein was placed on suicide watch following this incident and was scheduled for follow-up with psychology services.
The document records that during the clinical encounter, Epstein was 'ambulatory, oriented x 3,' in 'no apparent distress,' and was even 'smiling.'
